name: N-(3-chlorophenyl)-3,3,3-trifluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)propanamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4014
Reason: 3-Chlorophenyl and trifluoromethyl functionalities significantly increase the melting point due to the introduction of additional rigid structures and hydrogen bonding potential. The chlorine atom introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The fluorine atoms increase the molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +10°C per group, totaling +30°C. The trifluoromethyl group introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by about +20°C. The 3-chlorophenyl group introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions, raising the melting point by about +30°C. The piperidine ring introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions, raising the melting point by about +20°C.
